10004.description: Mock Interviews are a great way to prepare our program alumnus for the rigors of job searching and interviewing. Volunteers will interview between 2-4 program participants and provide them with quality feedback. We would greatly appreciate if you could come in and perform mock interviews with our recent program graduates as they are in the process of taking their next steps. Date: Wednesday, January 10th, 2018 Time: 1:00PM - 4:00PM Location: 85 Broad St New York, NY Apply via this link: https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/L9JH5CZ
10004.title: Help NYC's Urban Youth as a Mock Interviewer!

10004.description: Calling all residents of the Big Apple to help a fellow New Yorker get off the cold streets! On Monday, January 23rd, the NYC Department of Homeless Services from 10 PM to 4 AM (DHS) will conduct it's annual Homeless Outreach Population Estimate (HOPE), a citywide community volunteer effort to canvass parks, subways, and other public areas in order to determine the quantity of people who are without a home. YOU can help us collect vital information that is used by Outreach teams to help homeless people and connect them to the appropriate services they need! The information gathered by volunteers during HOPE 2016 is critical to our ongoing efforts, but we NEED your help to make it possible. We strive to recruit as many volunteers as we possibly can, age 18 and older, to just give up merely ONE night of their time to make an impact on someone less fortunate living on the streets. Volunteers are needed throughout the city, so there are multiple volunteer sites in all five boroughs and all volunteers will be trained prior to participation. Everyone will start and end the night at the volunteer site they choose. Please encourage friends, family and colleagues who may be interested in volunteering. Sign up for HOPE 2017 today to change someone's life on January 23rd,2017.
10004.title: CHANGE SOMEONE'S LIFE WITH THE HOMELESS OUTREACH POPULATION ESTIMATE (HOPE) 2018:
10004.org: New York City Department of Homeless Services

10004.description: A Let’s Get Ready Access Coach is a volunteer position for current undergraduate college students or recent graduates interested in supporting high school students from low-income households through SAT preparation and college admissions guidance, many of whom will be the first generation to attend college. Let’s Get Ready Coaches are a part of a network of approximately 1,000 college students per year working together to help students build confidence to tackle the SAT and get to and through college. Coaches are expected to commit to: At least one night a week (3 hours) of direct tutoring and mentoring with a group of 5-7 high school students 1.5 hours a week to prepare for each week’s lesson and to communicate with students about homework questions, attendance reminders, and other support. Let’s Get Ready provides training and ongoing support for all of its Coaches. Initial training is based around the SAT, its structure, and how to effectively engage a classroom of high school students. Secondary trainings are conducted by Let’s Get Ready Site Directors and focus on how to improve and give Coaches a chance to highlight some aspects of their role that are going really well. Throughout programming, Let’s Get Ready staff supports Coaches with a variety of resources and professional development opportunities as well as in-person observations and feedback. Let’s Get Ready also provides lesson plans for each week of programming. We encourage coaches to be innovative and creative when implementing lesson plans and tailoring classes to the skill level of the students. Position Responsibilities: Classroom Management and SAT Preparation Provide SAT preparation (either Math or Writing and Language) to a group of 5 to 7 high school students from low-income families Use classroom management techniques to keep students engaged in each lesson Prepare lessons for each class night, taking into account student needs and areas of growth Communication and Relationship Building Consistently communicate with students outside of class to help with homework completion and overall engagement in the program Work effectively with Site Directors and fellow Coaches throughout the program to build a strong network of leadership for your students Engage with all students throughout programming to not only build, but maintain strong relationships Help foster a college success culture through Let’s Get Ready’s College Choice curriculum College Admission Support Engage students in conversations centered around college by guiding them through the College Choice Checklist Encourage a college-going culture in the classroom Lead weekly activities and discussion about the college admissions process Support the initial phases of developing a college essay Who we look for: Let’s Get Ready seeks passionate individuals who are committed to the mission of providing educational resources and support to all students. Our Coaches are team players, focused on doing whatever it takes to help students gain the confidence that is needed to begin the college-going process. Questions? Contact zsmolen@letsgetready.org to learn more or apply online at https://www.tfaforms.com/4646037
10004.title: Calling all college students who are passionate about education & mentorship!

10004.description: Fraunces Tavern Museum is always looking to invite talented individuals to assist with our educational programming. Our well trained volunteer School Program Educators ensure the continual success of our educational mission. If you have a passion for history and hope to share that interest with others, you would be a great addition to our team of educators! Requirements Available to volunteer for at least 1 weekly School Program (approx. 90 minutes long). Comfortable administering inquiry-based learning and hands-on activities with students K-12. Interest in New York City history as it relates to Colonial America, the Revolutionary War, and the Early Republic. Responsibilities: Conduct exhibit-based school programs for K-12 students in the Museum’s galleries and period rooms. Use various educational strategies to lead school programs and engage students with the Museum’s collection. Set-up & break-down of school program’s supplies and spaces. Expectations: Able to work with a team; is enthusiastic, dependable and flexible. Enjoys interacting with the public and communicates effectively with individuals, families, and school groups. Willing to learn new information through hands-on experience and materials provided by the Education & Public Programs Director. Capable of 2-4 hours of physical activity. Benefits: This is a great opportunity for those interested in enhancing their public speaking skills and gaining experience in working with various populations in an educational setting. Benefits include free admission to the museum and its lectures, exhibit openings, eligibility for a free monthly MetroCard, and an annual volunteer luncheon and dinner. We need volunteers to ensure the success of our educational programming, so you would truly be making a difference. Former teaching or public speaking experience is a plus. Training involves receiving an Educator manual, shadowing tours, and subsequent Educator meetings. If interested please submit a resume and cover letter to: Jacqueline Masseo, Director of Education & Public Programs Email: 2education@frauncestavernmuseum.org
10004.title: School Program Educator

10007.description: Day One partners with New York City youth to end dating abuse and intimate partner violence through community education, counseling, legal advocacy and youth leadership development. We use an empowerment model that invests young people in maintaining safe relationships for themselves and their peers. Day One is seeking an undergraduate or graduate student, or a community member, to participate in a part-time, unpaid Development and Special Event internship opportunity from January 2018 until May 2018. This position will report to and work closely with the Development Manager. Primary responsibilities include: Assist in the planning and execution of Day One's annual Voices Against Violence Gala (April 18, 2018) Manage the silent auction: help solicit donations, track and coordinate delivery items, create packages and design marketing materials Manage sponsor and attendee contact and registration information Outreach and coordination of event day volunteers Assist with event day logistics and setup Draft donor communications such as acknowledgement letters and silent auction follow up Provide administrative support and perform other duties as assigned Qualifications: Previous event planning and fundraising experience a plus, not a must Superior organizational and communication skills Strong attention to detail and a demonstrated ability to take initiative Proficient in Microsoft Office applications, google drive and strong internet skills required HOW TO APPLY Please submit a cover letter and resume to Lindsay Mitcher, Development Manager, by email to lmitcher@dayoneny.org using the subject line \"Development & Special Events Volunteer\".
10007.title: Development & Special Events Volunteer

10001.description: Volunteers needed for Holiday Parties for Homeless Children!! The Actors Theatre Workshop (ATW), a nonprofit theater and community center, needs adult volunteers to mentor homeless children at our annual Builders of the New World Holiday Celebration on Tuesday, 12/12 and Wednesday, 12/13 from 1:30-8:30pm or 3:30-8:30pm. Being displaced by homelessness does not always allow the children the opportunity to have a traditional family gathering complete with hot nutritious food and special gifts. Share your love and compassion, and help these precious children reconnect to the dream and essence of the Holiday Season. Be a part of our 22nd annual holiday celebrations and creative classes for children living in five different NYC temporary housing facilities. If you’d like to work with the children, complete a volunteer application actorstheatreworkshop.com/holiday-parties , and attend a mandatory training session with ATW’s Artistic Director on either Sat, 12/2 or Sat 12/9 (from 4:00 - 7:00 PM), or Tues, 12/5 (from 6:30 - 9:30 PM). For more information visit actorstheatreworkshop.com/BNW-Holidays/ , contact us at outreach@actorstheatreworkshop.com, or call ATW at 212-947-1386. Check out this short video of a past holiday party and class and see for yourself the joy and fun the children experience!
10001.title: Volunteers needed for Holiday Parties for Homeless Children!!

10001.description: NOTE: ALL SHIFTS ON CHRISTMAS EVE & DAY ARE NOW BOOKED TO CAPACITY, AS ARE SEVERAL OTHER PLANNED EVENTS IN THE DAYS PRIOR. THE ONLY REMAINING ACTIVITIES AVAILABLE ARE SELECT PRE-HOLIDAY CELEBRATIONS AND MEALS ON DECEMBER 21. One of New York City's largest and most comprehensive social services agencies, Bowery Residents' Committee (BRC) serves men and women who are homeless, or at risk of becoming so, most of whom suffer from mental illness, substance addiction, or a combination. BRC gives our clients the knowledge and skills to stay sober and healthy and the sense of responsibility and value to find and maintain a home--in other words, the means to achieve permanent independence. BRC helps these neediest New Yorkers overcome the challenges of addiction, physical and mental illness, and poverty, and improves life in the community. We are committed in our mission to help the homeless of New York City and are always happy to hear from others who have the same passion and desire to make a difference. Volunteers are critical in allowing us to continue in our work; we absolutely value our volunteers' dedication and hope you contact us this holiday season. We have multiple locations throughout Manhattan and Brooklyn (see below) that will be serving meals and providing various celebrations to our clients & residents around the Christmas holiday, both on the day itself, as well Eve, and in the days prior. If you are interested, in order to receive an assignment, all volunteers must complete our New Volunteer Registration form in advance ( http://www.brc.org/volunteer-registration ). Once received, you will receive an invitation to our next scheduled orientation so you can learn more about BRC, what we do within the community and how you can help. Please be aware that attendance to one orientation is mandatory in order to receive an assignment. When completing your form at the link provided above, please make sure that you do emphasize your interest in \"HOLIDAY SERVICE\" so that we can be sure to include you in those communications. Further, our next available seasonally specific orientation sessions are the following; all will be held at BRC's administrative offices on 25th Street. You only need attend one; please email in advance: Thursday, December 14, 6pm to 7pm Sunday, December 17, 12pm to 1pm As you can see from the very short list of available shifts noted below, we do have a handful of shifts available at pre-holiday celebrations, however we are at capacity for Christmas day. Please take a moment to review what is open, and select a volunteer shift day, time and location. I can hold that spot, thus guaranteeing you the opportunity to volunteer, provided you do attend the orientation previously mentioned. Note: Volunteers must be at least 18 years of age or older to participate. Some locations do have very limited availability for those individuals that are high school age. All minors must be accompanied by a parent or legal guardian, with prior written consent. 2017 PRE-CHRISTMAS ACTIVITIES, EVENTS & MEALS Program Name: BRC HomePlus Location: Hosted at Delancey Street near Chrystie Street # Volunteer Positions Remaining: 1 Time: 4pm to 7pm Date: Thursday, December 21 Task: Volunteers are needed for set-up, meal service, as well as stay for post dinner clean-up. Program Name: BRC Men’s Assessment Shelter Location: Clay Street at McGuiness Blvd, Greenpoint, Brooklyn # Volunteer Positions Remaining: 2 Time: 11am to 2:30pm Date: Thursday, December 21 Task: Volunteers are needed for set-up, meal service in two shifts (12-1 & 1-2), as well as stay for post dinner clean-up. Program Name: Cecil Ivory House Location: 132nd Street between 7th Avenue and Lenox # Volunteer Positions Remaining: 2 Time: 2pm to 6pm Date: Thursday, December 21 Task: Volunteers are needed to help with meal preparation, dining room set-up, decorating and dinner service, socializing and post dinner clean-up. Program Name: Casa de los Vecinos Location: 91 Pitt Street just south of East Houston # Volunteer Positions Remaining: 2 Time: 2pm to 7pm Date: Thursday, December 21 Task: Volunteers are needed to help with meal preparation, dining room set-up, decorating and dinner service, socializing and post dinner clean-up. If you would like more information, please feel free to contact our Director of Volunteer Services, Rick Akin, at 212-803-5720 or via email at rakin@brc.org Many thanks in advance and happy holidays!
10001.title: Help Serve New York City's Homeless this Holiday Season

10001.description: GO Project - Avenues the World School PROGRAM DESCRIPTION Each Saturday, a group of registered 1st - 5th grade students from GO Project's public school partners and 1st - 5th grade students from the Avenues School will participate in FREE enrichment classes on the Avenues Campus together. Classes will be offered to grades 1-5, first come, first serve, and will include: Dance, Drama, Studio Arts, Parkour, and Music (programs that have felt the deepest cuts in the NYC Public School system). Professional instructors will see the same group of students for 10 sessions, every other weekend, so that there is a chance for community-building, skill development, and benefit of instruction. PROGRAM LOGISTICS Each Saturday from November 18 - April 21 Class Time: 1:00 PM - 2:00 PM (instructors can arrive early to prepare) GO Students are fed from 12:30 PM - 12:55 PM and dismissed directly to classes. Volunteers will support an Avenues enrichment instructor from 1:00 PM - 2:00 PM to support the enrichment learning for students grades 1-5. CLASSES/DATES Grade 1 Parkour JR. 16 Students Spider-Man, Captain America, Batman, Aladdin. What do they all have in common? They do parkour. This class will focus on how to overcome obstacles using only your body and the principal patterns of movement such as sprinting, climbing, jumping, rolling and vaulting. Join this class and start your parkour training in a safe and controlled environment with New York City’s premier parkour instructor Bryce Clarke. NOVEMBER 18 DECEMBER 9 JANUARY 20 FEBRUARY 3, 24 MARCH 10 APRIL 7 Grade 2 The Poetry of Dance Jr. 16 Students Learn about self-expression through movement with a focus on Latin dance. Director Ra Ruiz Leon of Xianix Barrera Flamenco has taught all ages of students how to tell stories through both traditional and non-traditional dances and is herself an accomplished dancer and slam poet. A wonderful way to get your children active and creative together. The class will end with a performance developed by the students. NOVEMBER 18 DECEMBER 9 JANUARY 20 FEBRUARY 3, 24 MARCH 10 APRIL 7 Grade 3 For the Love of Music 16 Students Take a journey of self-expression through music. Everything from drum jams to original composition will be covered in a class that is designed to inspire musical curiosity in your children. Led by two of Avenues’ most accomplished musicians and UD Students, the class is designed to show students how music is its own sophisticated language that they themselves can 'speak’. DECEMBER 2, 16 JANUARY 27 FEBRUARY 10 MARCH 3, 17 APRIL 14 Grade 4 Parkour 16 Students Spider-Man, Captain America, Batman, Aladdin. What do they all have in common? They do parkour. This class will focus on how to overcome obstacles using only your body and the principal patterns of movement such as sprinting, climbing, jumping, rolling and vaulting. Join this class and start your parkour training in a safe and controlled environment with New York City’s premier parkour instructor Bryce Clarke. DECEMBER 2, 16 JANUARY 27 FEBRUARY 10 MARCH 3, 17 APRIL 14 Grade 5 The Poetry of Dance 16 Students Learn about self-expression through movement with a focus on Latin dance. Director Ra Ruiz of Sabor Flamenco has taught all ages of students how to tell stories through both traditional and non-traditional dances and is herself an accomplished dancer and slam poet. A wonderful way to get your children active and creative together. The class will end with a performance developed by the students. DECEMBER 2, 16 JANUARY 27 FEBRUARY 10 MARCH 3, 17 APRIL 14 APRIL 21: CULMINATING EVENT Presented on the 5 th Floor commons, each class will have 5 minutes to present a culminating activity to showcase the work that they did together as a class. Parents, teachers and students will have a chance to say 'goodbye’ for the school year and it coincides with the Avenues GO School final celebration.
10001.title: GO Project Enrichment Volunteers Needed: Saturday Afternoon!

10001.description: GO Project Spanish Translator (Saturday Volunteer) GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Programming: How YOU Can Help GO Schoolis a focused, seven-month Saturday program with a staff of certified teachers and skilled volunteer tutors. Students attend on Saturdays between October and April for a half-day of focused academic skill-building. Professional teachers lead lessons, support volunteer tutors, and communicate with parents to keep them informed about their child’s progress. Volunteer tutors commit to a semester of volunteering in a classroom and mentor their students to provide consistent and individualized needed to succeed. Volunteer translators provide critical communication support between our GO families and our staff. Interpreters are responsible for translating English into Spanish in order for our program to communicate with our families regarding program updates and their child’s academic & social-emotional progress/needs. Specific Translator duties will include: Saturdays Assist with parent meetings, workshops and orientations for Spanish speaking families. Provide interpretation for our families, including any cultural/linguistic references that may need to be explained. Maintain our families’ right to confidentiality. Collaborate with GO Staff, Volunteer Manager, Head Teachers and GO Families Staff to address and respond to our students’/ families’ needs. Time Commitment The position would require a commitment to our GO School Saturday program. We can accommodate a semester schedule or a full year commitment. Session I: October- December 2017, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2018, 13 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications: Excellent verbal and written communication skills. Interest in strength-based collaborative work, education and social services. Ability to speak Spanish. Prior experience in simultaneous and consecutive interpretation is a plus. Personal Attributes: The ideal candidate is exceptionally intelligent, warm, engaging and energetic. He or she also: Sees the possibilities as opposed to the obstacles and is creative and tenacious in solving problems. Enjoys working with others in a collaborative, creative environment. Has a strong work ethic and high standards for his/her own work and the work of others; is flexible and has a lively sense of humor. Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development and training opportunities. Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment. Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community. How to Apply Application Form Cover Letter/Personal Statement explaining why you want to volunteer with the GO Project Resume (for volunteers 18 and older)/ High school transcript (for HS students) Personal reference Background check (for those 18 and older) If interested, please fill out the online form at: https://goo.gl/forms/iGs9YOzEUsNCujrk2 . The online application form can also be found on the GO Project website: goprojectnyc.org under \"Get Involved\" and \"Volunteer Opportunities.\" If you have any questions or would like more information about the available volunteer positions, please contact Emily Ong, Community Engagement Program Manager, at eong@goprojectnyc.org.
10001.title: Saturday Spanish Translator Needed!

10001.description: GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Tutoring: How YOU Can Help During the GO School Saturday program, a professional teacher models a lesson, activity or project to a classroom of students. Volunteer tutors continue to work with small groups of (2) to (4) students on the lesson providing individualized attention which allows the students to thrive. Tutor Responsibilities Tutor small group of students in grades 1 st-8 th who are in need of academic intervention under Head Teacher’s guidance Punctual and consistent attendance; no more than 3 absences permitted per session. (Session 1: Oct-Dec, Session 2: Jan-April) Actively and enthusiastically participate - supporting instruction and engagement Help prepare, record and put away classroom materials Ongoing communication with Head Teacher regarding children’s progress &/or concerns, and with the Director of Community Engagement regarding overall volunteer experience. Time Commitment Session I: October- December 2017, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2018, 14 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Attend mandatory orientation and training prior to start of session. *You can choose to be a Committed Volunteer to come each Saturday with 3 allowed absences per session, or a Floater Volunteer to come on the Saturdays that you are available. GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations You can choose to tutor our students at one of the following 6 locations: Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications College students, professionals, retirees, and high school students in good academic standing. Commitment to and belief in all children’s ability to succeed and thrive Professional work habits Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development and training opportunities. Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment. Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community. How to Apply Application Form Cover Letter/Personal Statement explaining why you want to volunteer with the GO Project Resume (for volunteers 18 and older)/ High school transcript (for HS students) Personal reference Background check (for those 18 and older) If interested, please fill out the online form at: https://goo.gl/forms/iGs9YOzEUsNCujrk2 . The online application form can also be found on the GO Project website: goprojectnyc.org under \"Get Involved\" and \"Volunteer Opportunities.\" If you have any questions or would like more information about the available volunteer positions, please contact Emily Ong, Community Engagement Program Manager, at eong@goprojectnyc.org.

10001.description: Building Community Bridges, Inc. is looking for an Administrative Assistant who is passionate about social justice with excellent interpersonal skills and at least two years prior administrative experience, preferably with a nonprofit organization. Proficiency in Microsoft Office (Word; Excel; PowerPoint) is required along with excellent organizational skills and attention to detail. We are looking for someone with the ability to meet deadlines while managing multiple projects both independently and/or on a team. We invite you to join us as we innovate solutions for transformation in rural communities in West Africa.
10001.title: Administrative Assistant

10001.description: ESOL school for immigrants and refugees, educating since 1997, is looking for a qualified and efficient administrator. The most important qualification is bilingual in Japanese. Experience with immigrants a plus. Duties will include: Intake amd registration of new students. Assisting with document preparation and mailings. Answering phone calls from students regarding class times and scheduling. Making appointments for ESOL testing. Keeping organised lists of pertinent student information.
10001.title: Japanese Speaking Program Assistant

10002.description: We are a small growing environmental nonprofit with a budget of around $75,000 We have two summer camps with 1099 employees We work with NYS discretionary funds and submit receipts for reimbursements. Experienced with online QuickBooks
10002.title: Experienced online QuickBooks bookkeeper helping nonprofit enhance community gardens

10002.description: We are looking for individuals who have the skills listed below to help us a fundraising event called Rock Against Dementia for our organization. Possess excellent social networking skills Ability to generate relevant information regarding the use of money Possess excellent research and development skills Charismatic and possess excellent customer service skills Possess effective oral and written communication skills Self-motivated, creative and possess excellent organizational skills Possess sound analytical and problem-solving skills Ability to accomplish tasks within limited time period Possess excellent time management skills Knowledge of all major operating systems like Microsoft Windows, Microsoft Office, and the Internet Ability to perform tasks in a collaborative and consultative manner We would love to have you on our team.
10002.title: Fundraising Event Volunteers

10002.description: Empower a young person to succeed by tutoring in core subject areas to help them achieve their goals this school year and beyond! WHAT IS YOUR COMMITMENT AS A TUTOR? · Work one-on-one or in small group setting with students in a core subject area to provide academic support · Available weekly (Monday-Friday) -Mondays and Fridays from 4-5 PM or 5-6 PM -Tuesdays, Wednesdays, and Thursdays from 4-8 PM for one hour increments · Serve as a role model, providing guidance and support · Subjects needed: English, Math (Algebra 1&2, Geometry, Trigonometry, and Pre-calculus), Science (Living Environment, Chemistry, and Physics), History (Global, US), Test Prep APPLY TO BE A TUTOR IF... · Current college student or college graduates (must be 18 ) · You have experience or willingness to build a working relationship with youth · Strong knowledge of the subject(s) area that you will be tutoring
10002.title: Academic Subject-Based Tutors

10002.description: OVERVIEW Global Potential (GP) is looking for a skilled Marketing & Social Media Coordinator who will work directly with our Chief Marketing Officer to coordinate the integration of Global Potential’s marketing strategy with that of its acquiring organization. The Marketing & Social Media Coordinator will report directly to the Chief Marketing Officer and play a key role in the organization’s Acquisition Task Force. The ideal candidate should demonstrate a strong commitment to the mission and values of Global Potential and should have substantial expertise in all areas of responsibility. RESPONSIBILITIES Managing Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Youtube, Linkedin internal and external social media posts. Ensuring the organization's message is distributed across channels and to targeted audiences Producing social media content and newsletters per GP’s vision and strategy Supervising youth social media interns working on content, collaborating with Webmaster with updates and technical support of the website Seeking out new ways to deliver messaging, such as web platforms, video and social media Working with CMO and CEO in creating Annual Report IDEAL CANDIDATE EXPERIENCE AND SKILLS 1-3 years of experience in social media and marketing Basic knowledge of non-profit environment in New York City Excellent attention to detail and strong organizational skills Adept social, interpersonal, and written communication skills Ability to demonstrate strong leadership while being a flexible, self-motivated, team-oriented Skills in Adobe Experience in youth-friendly environment preferred Written and Oral communication proficiency in Spanish and/or Haitian Creole is a plus Bachelor’s Degree preferred Digitally curious and savvy Knowledge of photography, videography and editing helpful. COMMITMENT This is a part-time volunteer position requiring interaction with the Global Potential youth and youth social media interns MINIMUM EDUCATION REQUIRED: 4-year degree HOW TO APPLY: Please submit your resume and cover letter to hr@global-potential.org In your submission, please describe how your interests, skills and experience are a fit with the position as described above. Global Potential is an equal opportunity employer and hires without discrimination to gender, race, ethnicity, sexual preference or birthplace of origin. Global Potential provides a generous vacation and leave package, and compensation is aligned with industry standards and commensurate with experience. ABOUT GLOBAL POTENTIAL Global Potential is an innovative local & international youth development organization that transforms youth from under-served communities through education, service learning and cultural exchange into globally competitive leaders of positive change in their lives and communities. GP is headquartered in NYC. Since our founding in 2007, 100% of our youth Fellows have graduated from high school, 87% entered college and a growing number enter graduate school. Youth-driven community action projects result in award-winning documentary films, advocacy and service initiatives, and solidarity projects with rural villages in Haiti, Dominican Republic, and Nicaragua. GP youth are ethnically and nationally diverse and hail from our cities’ most underserved communities.
10002.title: Social Media Coordinator

10002.description: WHAT IS YOUR COMMITMENT AS A TUTOR? · Work one-on-one or in small group setting with students on SAT prep · Wednesday evenings from 6:30-8 · Serve as a role model, providing guidance and support APPLY TO BE A TUTOR IF... · Current college student or college graduates (must be 18 ) · You have experience or willingness to build a working relationship with youth · Strong knowledge of the subject(s) area that you will be tutoring HOW TO GET STARTED! · Complete our Volunteer Application and include the following info in the additional information section: -Your availability -What subjects you feel comfortable tutoring High School students in. Please be specific (i.e. type of science, type of math, etc.) · Prospective tutors will have a phone screening call, in-person meeting with program staff and SCR background check BENEFITS FOR OUR VOLUNTEERS! · Gain knowledge of working in an after-school program, while giving back to your community · Access to volunteer meet-ups, which include learning, social and networking opportunities, · Tracking of your volunteer hours for your company, school or affiliated group
10002.title: SAT Prep Mentors

10002.description: Global Potential's mission is to empower youth and communities around the world to energize each other through education, international service learning, social entrepreneurship and cultural exchange. Each year, Global Potential trains 500 youth aged between 15 to 23. These youth have high potential and self-vision to become leaders, change makers and social entrepreneurs in their urban and rural low-income communities around the world. Most GP participants are first generation immigrant youth and originate from dozens of countries. Global Potential's holistic model positively transforms the lives of urban youth.They shape the future and become leaders and entrepreneurs in business, community development, education and politics. For more information please visit www.global-potential.org The College and Career Access Coordinator will be responsible for facilitating college and career readiness workshops with GP youth (high school juniors and seniors), compiling opportunities for youth in transition (scholarships, gap year programs, internships), and coordinating youth's participation in college and career events. Responsibilities include: Engage with GP Alumni to support them in their role as peer mentors Compile resources for postsecondary opportunities, including college applications, scholarships, internships, and gap year programs Provide coaching in writing resumes and personal statements Assist the Program Manager in preparing deliverables to the program funder Gather and maintain data in our Salesforce database system Coordinate college and career events with GP partner organization and high schools, including Q & A panels with GP Alumni Collaborate with Program Coordinators to plan and facilitate GP workshops Experience with serving undocumented youth in preparation for college (i.e. access to scholarships, outsourcing to organizations like the Door for applying for residency, having a roster of translators-specifically for our African youth). Requirements for this position: Experience in compiling college and career opportunities for high school youth Minimum of 3 months, preferably 6 months commitment. Minimum of 10-15 hours per week Available to work in the office at least one day/week Flexible to work offsite at GP's partner high schools Experience with Salesforce or any other database management system is not required but preferred; GP will provide training No language requirements; Spanish, Haitian Creole, or French preferred Currently attending College in New York City; College Degree in any discipline preferred. This is a pilot program so there is an opportunity to bring one's own creativity and ideas to further develop the program. This position reports to and works collaboratively with the Program Manager. We are looking for an immediate start. If interested in this role, please send your resume to hr@global-potential.org indicating the title, ' College and Career Access Coordinator', in the subject line.
10002.title: College and Career Readiness Coordinator

10002.description: Reading Empowers was formed with the mission of improving literacy among young children. Our goal is to instill an interest in reading, at a young age, and our hope is that this will develop into a lifelong love and passion. This upcoming school semester (Fall 2017), we will be hosting Saturday morning reading sessions at P.S. 1 and P.S. 124, both in Lower Manhattan. These sessions are twice a month, generally, every other Saturday from 10:00AM - 12:30PM. Each session is about two hours. Volunteers and students are broken up into groups, with each group consisting of 2-3 volunteers and 6-10 students. The sessions consist of reading, writing, and an arts and crafts activity with the students. We are looking for volunteers to join us on our mission! We will be reading to students in 1st, 2nd, and 3rd Grade. P.S. 1 and P.S. 124 are both located in Chinatown at 8 Henry Street and 40 Division Street, repsectively, in LES Manhattan. Below are the dates for the Fall 2017 and Spring 2018 dates are not finalized yet but will share the dates once available. Reading Empowers is a non-profit organization in the state of New York and recognized as a tax-exempt 501(c)(3) organization by the IRS. Please feel free to visit our website http://www.readingempowers.org/ Requirements Volunteers must be 18 or older New volunteers must pass the background check with our vendor, Go Pass. There is a $60 background check fee that will be reimbursed to you after you volunteer with us for 60% of all the sessions in one full school year ~ 8-9 sessions We are looking for consistent commitment for this school year, which is roughly two Saturdays per month To get involved please fill out our online application at: www.readingempowers.org/application
10002.title: Read to 1st, 2nd or 3rd Graders in a public school in Lower Manhattan!

10002.description: Cabrini Immigrant Services of NYC, Inc. (CIS-NYC) is currently looking for passionate and experienced volunteer ESL teachers for the 2017-18 academic year. If you love teaching, have patience and a sense of humor, come join our wonderful cadre of teachers and adult learners. Classes meet twice a week for 2 hours starting the week of Sept. 11. Days and times are flexible. Cabrini Immigrant Services of NYC, Inc. (CIS-NYC) is a multi-service community and faith-based non-profit that provides a broad range of culturally and linguistically appropriate services to immigrants, refugees, asylees, and their families. CIS-NYC meets the unique needs of diverse immigrant populations through supportive services and concrete assistance which encourage economic independence and social empowerment, foster individual growth and development, and promote self-determination for immigrant families, children and youth.
10002.title: VOLUNTEER ESL TEACHER
10002.org: CABRINI IMMIGRANT SERVICES OF NEW YORK CITY INC

10002.description: Operations Coordinator The Operations Associate helps ensure that the Vietnam Heritage Center’s Vietnamese School runs smoothly by assisting with school-wide logistics, including registration support, class scheduling, and communications throughout the semester. While this position does not require volunteers to attend classes, VHC would be pleased to offer you free tuition for one semester in return for your help. QUALIFICATIONS Must have advanced fluency in English. Familiarity with Vietnamese preferred but not required. Volunteers should be organized and detail-oriented with regular access to email and the Internet. Must be familiar with or willing to learn how to use online platforms such as SquareSpace, G Suite, and MailChimp. REQUIRED COMMITMENT Must be available for at least 1 semester of classes (12 weeks) for 1-2 hours per week. Most work can be done remotely at home, but there may be instances where volunteers may have to come to the Vietnamese School to assist with in-class logistics.
10002.title: Volunteer Language School Operations Coordinator

10002.description: Vietnamese Teaching Assistant Teaching Assistants at the Vietnam Heritage Center’s Vietnamese School help teachers with class logistics such as attendance, homework, and proper note-taking. They also support students by answering questions and giving feedback during class. This is a unique opportunity to help others and engage with a diverse group of students while further honing your own Vietnamese teaching skills in class. QUALIFICATIONS Must have advanced fluency in English and fluency in Vietnamese is preferred, along with reliable transportation to school on a weekly basis. Prior experience with teaching preferred but not required. REQUIRED COMMITMENT Must be able to assist with classes 2 hours/week for 12 weeks in the spring or fall. Additional time may be required to support teachers with logistics and lesson plans.
10002.title: Volunteer Teaching Assistant

10002.description: Teacher Teachers at the Vietnam Heritage Center’s Vietnamese School lead Vietnamese classes at all levels, helping students develop skills in reading, writing, listening, and speaking. They also educate students on Vietnamese culture and customs. As a teacher, you’ll have the opportunity to help others, share your knowledge, and engage with a diverse group of students and individuals. QUALIFICATIONS Must have advanced fluency in English and Vietnamese and reliable means of transportation to school on a weekly basis. Prior experience with teaching preferred but not required. REQUIRED COMMITMENT Must be able to teach 2 hours/week for 12 weeks in the spring or fall. Additional time will also be required to develop lesson plans for students.
10002.title: Volunteer Teacher

10002.description: The LEAD Program Our program strives to combat educational inequity during the hours after school. Our program seeks to provide quality, afterschool educational services in communities that normally do not have access or opportunities for academic advancement. We hire experienced, classroom teachers who believe that all students can should be able to attain quality after school educational services regardless of socio-economic background. Afterschool Tutors at LEAD: Are looking for an afterschool position with purpose and potential to impact the community Are seeking to build a meaningful, one-on-one relationship with a student over the course of several months to a year Are looking to make meaningful change Responsibilities: Leading the children to academic success by conducting meaningful, impactful one on one tutoring sessions at the learning center Being an authority figure with the student and having solid behavior management Ability to effectively communicate with parents regarding student performance Orientation/Training Date: First week of September Start Date for Tuting: October 2017 Position Requirements: 1+ years of tutoring experience Ability to connect with elementary-aged children from diverse, urban backgrounds Ability to speak Spanish is a plus, but not required Ability to speak Mandarin Chinese is a plus, but not required Commitment of at least the full school year is preferred, but not required Work Schedule: Flushing, Queens Location: Varies Mondays through Fridays between 4:30pm - 6pm Lower East Side of Manhattan Location: Varies Mondays through Fridays between 4:30pm - 6pm
10002.title: Volunteer Tutor for Afterschool Learning Center

10002.description: Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade. Reading is the foundation for all future learning.The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life. With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency. No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm. Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.
10002.title: Become a reading partner- make a lifelong impact on a child (PS140 Nathan Straus, Manhattan)

10003.description: Recruiting Seasonal Retail Volunteers! Nomi Network is a fast-growing non-profit working to end human trafficking through economic opportunities & transparent supply chains. Human trafficking is a modern-day form of slavery and it is the second most prevalent crime in the world as of today. Nomi Network endeavors to tackle the root cause of the problem - poverty. We train women to create quality products, and we sell the products online, in retail stores and at direct-sales events. Proceeds from sales go back to the women’s development, education and further training. We help partner organizations hire more survivors or at risk women to produce these products as well. Through training and job placement, Nomi Network combats poverty by increasing the financial independence of these women. Job Overview: During the holiday season, Nomi Network operates retail booths at Union Square and Columbus Circle holiday markets in New York City. We are looking for passionate, self-motivated volunteers with at least 1 to 2 years of retail, food and beverage, and customer service experience to assist us with sales. We are recruiting individuals who are goal-oriented, charismatic closers: who will help generate revenue by securing in-person sales, engage customers, and work collaboratively sales associates, other volunteers, product ambassadors, and managers. We seek individuals who are passionate about our mission and our products, and who clearly see and communicate the linkage between product sales and creating freedom for those women in our programs. Volunteer shifts are three to four consecutive hours long, on average. We welcome volunteers with the availability of at least three hours (one shift) per week between November 16th - December 24th to apply. Responsibilities: Acknowledge customers in a friendly and helpful manner Provide customers with details about merchandise including special product features, pricing, design, and construction Provide each customer with details about sale items and current promotions Respond to customers’ requests and concerns in a resourceful manner Arrange products in a tidy and appealing manner Execute proper cash handling by taking cash or credit cards in exchange of goods sold Discourage shoplifting activities Be punctual and maintain regular attendance Requirements: Ability to work successfully and independently, but also work collaboratively with others Ability to multitask Ability to pay close attention to detail Must be an entrepreneurial, self-starter Must be able to take initiative Must be reliable and responsible Must be an articulate speaker with excellent oral and written communication skills Must possess government issued identification Must be available to work November 16th through December 24th in N.Y.C. Send your resume and cover letter to nominetworkrecruiter@gmail.com. Please write \"Holiday Volunteer\" in the subject line. We would love to meet our volunteers for an informal interview sometime between October 26th and November 3rd. We also ask that volunteers make time for a brief onboarding/sales device training on Monday, November 6th. Thank you, Nomi Network Recruiter
10003.title: Volunteers Wanted for Nonprofit Holiday Market

10003.description: We are currently looking for Volunteer Office Assistants to work in the afternoon and/or the evening. Volunteer Office Assistants serve 4-6 hours per week for a prestigious downtown NYC community theater that produces 25-30 new plays and 3 free community events each year. Volunteer Office Assistants will answer phones, take reservations, file papers and occasionally assist Executive Director Crystal Field by writing letters or researching on the internet. Opportunities available specifically on weekdays in the Morning/Afternoons from 10am to 4pm, or in the evenings from 4pm to 10pm, or on weekends from 12pm to 8pm. Volunteers will receive FREE tickets to all TNC productions.
10003.title: Administrative Assistance

10003.description: GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO Fundamentals Tutoring: How YOU Can Help GO Fundamentals, is a tutoring program for GO Project K-8 students who have been identified as \"promotion in doubt\" by their public schools. (Promotion in Doubt means a student may need to repeat their current grade). GO Fundamentals provides the students with additional academic time on literacy development. By working with the students on a more individualized basis, we will give them more opportunities to master the reading and writing skills needed to be promoted to the next grade in June. GO Fundamentals 2018 Session Dates February 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14 Qualifications College students, professionals, retirees, and high school students in good academic standing. Commitment to and belief in all children’s ability to succeed and thrive. Professional work habits. Tutor Responsibilities Tutor one-to-one or in small groups students who are in need of academic intervention. Punctual and consistent attendance; advanced notification of absences necessary. Actively and enthusiastically participate - supporting instruction and engagement. Help prepare, record, and put away classroom materials. Ongoing communication with the program staff regarding student’s progress &/or concerns, and overall volunteer experience. Time Commitment February-April, Saturdays from 12:30 PM - 2:00 PM. Attend mandatory orientation and training prior to start of session. Location You can choose to tutor our students at one of the following 6 locations: Manhattan Locations Avenues: The World School (1st-5th Grade): 259 10th Avenue, between 25th and 26th Streets Grace Church School (1st-5th Grade): 86 4th Avenue, between 10th and 11th Streets Grace Church High School (6th-8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6th Street LREI (1st-5th Grade): 272 6th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s School (1st-3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson and Christopher Streets Brooklyn Location Berkeley Carroll (1st- 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6th and 7th Avenues Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development opportunities Joining a strong volunteer community Participating in volunteer social events and outings How to Apply Application Form Cover Letter/Personal Statement explaining why you want to volunteer with GO Project Resume (for volunteers 18 and older)/High school transcript (for high school students) Personal reference Background check (for those 18 and older) If interested, please fill out the online form at: https://goo.gl/forms/iGs9YOzEUsNCujrk2. The online application form can also be found on our website at: http://goprojectnyc.org/get-involved/volunteer. If you have any questions or would like more information about the available volunteer positions, please contact volunteering@goprojectnyc.org or call 212-533-3744 ATTN: Olivia Nunez, Senior Director of Community Engagement.
10003.title: Help a Child Love to Learn on Saturday Afternoons!

We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications College students, professionals, retirees, and high school students in good academic standing. 10003.description: GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Programming: How YOU Can Help GO Schoolis a focused, seven-month Saturday program with a staff of certified teachers and skilled volunteer tutors. Students attend on Saturdays between October and April for a half-day of focused academic skill-building. Professional teachers lead lessons, support volunteer tutors, and communicate with parents to keep them informed about their child’s progress. Volunteer tutors commit to a semester of volunteering in a classroom and mentor their students to provide consistent and individualized needed to succeed. Volunteer translators provide critical communication support between our GO families and our staff. Interpreters are responsible for translating English into Chinese (both Mandarin and Cantonese) in order for our program to communicate with our families regarding program updates and their child’s academic & social-emotional progress/needs. Specific Translator duties will include: Saturdays Assist with parent meetings, workshops and orientations for Chinese speaking families. Provide interpretation for our families, including any cultural/linguistic references that may need to be explained. Maintain our families’ right to confidentiality. Collaborate with GO Staff, Volunteer Manager, Head Teachers and GO Families Staff to address and respond to our students’/ families’ needs. Time Commitment The position would require a commitment to our GO School Saturday program. We can accommodate a semester schedule or a full year commitment. Session I: October- December 2017, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2018, 13 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications: Excellent verbal and written communication skills. Interest in strength-based collaborative work, education and social services. Ability to speak both Mandarin and Cantonese is preferred. Prior experience in simultaneous and consecutive interpretation is a plus. Personal Attributes: The ideal candidate is exceptionally intelligent, warm, engaging and energetic. He or she also: Sees the possibilities as opposed to the obstacles and is creative and tenacious in solving problems. Enjoys working with others in a collaborative, creative environment. Has a strong work ethic and high standards for his/her own work and the work of others; is flexible and has a lively sense of humor. 10003.description: GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Tutoring: How YOU Can Help During the GO School Saturday program, a professional teacher models a lesson, activity or project to a classroom of students. Volunteer tutors continue to work with small groups of (2) to (4) students on the lesson providing individualized attention which allows the students to thrive. Tutor Responsibilities Tutor small group of students in grades 1 st-8 th who are in need of academic intervention under Head Teacher’s guidance Punctual and consistent attendance; no more than 3 absences permitted per session. (Session 1: Oct-Dec, Session 2: Jan-April) Actively and enthusiastically participate - supporting instruction and engagement Help prepare, record and put away classroom materials Ongoing communication with Head Teacher regarding children’s progress &/or concerns, and with the Director of Community Engagement regarding overall volunteer experience. Time Commitment Session I: October- December 2017, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2018, 14 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Attend mandatory orientation and training prior to start of session. *You can choose to be a Committed Volunteer to come each Saturday with 3 allowed absences per session, or a Floater Volunteer to come on the Saturdays that you are available. GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations You can choose to tutor our students at one of the following 6 locations: Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications College students, professionals, retirees, and high school students in good academic standing. Commitment to and belief in all children’s ability to succeed and thrive Professional work habits Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. 10003.title: Help a Child Love to Learn: Volunteer Tutor with GO Project!

10003.description: GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Programming: How YOU Can Help GO Schoolis a focused, seven-month Saturday program with a staff of certified teachers and skilled volunteer tutors. Students attend on Saturdays between October and April for a half-day of focused academic skill-building. Professional teachers lead lessons, support volunteer tutors, and communicate with parents to keep them informed about their child’s progress. Volunteer tutors commit to a semester of volunteering in a classroom and mentor their students to provide consistent and individualized needed to succeed. Volunteer translators provide critical communication support between our GO families and our staff. Interpreters are responsible for translating English into Chinese (both Mandarin and Cantonese) in order for our program to communicate with our families regarding program updates and their child’s academic & social-emotional progress/needs. Specific Translator duties will include: Saturdays Assist with parent meetings, workshops and orientations for Chinese speaking families. Provide interpretation for our families, including any cultural/linguistic references that may need to be explained. Maintain our families’ right to confidentiality. Collaborate with GO Staff, Volunteer Manager, Head Teachers and GO Families Staff to address and respond to our students’/ families’ needs. Time Commitment The position would require a commitment to our GO School Saturday program. We can accommodate a semester schedule or a full year commitment. Session I: October- December 2017, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2018, 13 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications: Excellent verbal and written communication skills. Interest in strength-based collaborative work, education and social services. Ability to speak both Mandarin and Cantonese is preferred. Prior experience in simultaneous and consecutive interpretation is a plus. Personal Attributes: The ideal candidate is exceptionally intelligent, warm, engaging and energetic. He or she also: Sees the possibilities as opposed to the obstacles and is creative and tenacious in solving problems. Enjoys working with others in a collaborative, creative environment. Has a strong work ethic and high standards for his/her own work and the work of others; is flexible and has a lively sense of humor. Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development and training opportunities. Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment. Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community. How to Apply Application Form Cover Letter/Personal Statement explaining why you want to volunteer with the GO Project Resume (for volunteers 18 and older)/ High school transcript (for HS students) Personal reference Background check (for those 18 and older) If interested, please fill out the online form at: https://goo.gl/forms/iGs9YOzEUsNCujrk2 . The online application form can also be found on the GO Project website: goprojectnyc.org under \"Get Involved\" and \"Volunteer Opportunities.\" If you have any questions or would like more information about the available volunteer positions, please contact Emily Ong, Community Engagement Program Manager, at eong@goprojectnyc.org.

10003.description: GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Tutoring: How YOU Can Help During the GO School Saturday program, a professional teacher models a lesson, activity or project to a classroom of students. Volunteer tutors continue to work with small groups of (2) to (4) students on the lesson providing individualized attention which allows the students to thrive. Tutor Responsibilities Tutor small group of students in grades 1 st-8 th who are in need of academic intervention under Head Teacher’s guidance Punctual and consistent attendance; no more than 3 absences permitted per session. (Session 1: Oct-Dec, Session 2: Jan-April) Actively and enthusiastically participate - supporting instruction and engagement Help prepare, record and put away classroom materials Ongoing communication with Head Teacher regarding children’s progress &/or concerns, and with the Director of Community Engagement regarding overall volunteer experience. Time Commitment Session I: October- December 2017, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2018, 14 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Attend mandatory orientation and training prior to start of session. High School students, those receiving credit or fulfilling a requirement must attend the training sessions offered. (All other volunteers are encouraged to attend.) GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations You can choose to tutor our students at one of the following 6 locations: Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications College students, professionals, retirees, and high school students in good academic standing. Commitment to and belief in all children’s ability to succeed and thrive Professional work habits Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development and training opportunities. Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment. Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community. How to Apply Application Form Cover Letter/Personal Statement explaining why you want to volunteer with the GO Project Resume (for volunteers 18 and older)/ High school transcript (for HS students) Personal reference Background check (for those 18 and older) If interested, please fill out the online form at: https://goo.gl/forms/iGs9YOzEUsNCujrk2 . 10003.description: Tutor the future of our city! Volunteer tutors are needed to work with the remarkable community at Manhattan Comprehensive Night and Day High School (MCNDHS)! MCNDHS is a public school whose students are between 17 and 22 years old, many of whom are recent immigrants and all of whom are working toward their NY State HS Regents diploma. Tutors are needed for all subjects, including: English(all levels, from basic conversation to advanced grammar/writing) Math(all levels, especially Algebra) Science (especially Biology and Earth Science) History (Global and U.S.) Tutors are needed Monday through Friday, from 10am to 8pm. 10003.description: GO Project Chinese Translator (Weekday Volunteer) GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Programming: How YOU Can Help GO School is a focused, seven-month Saturday program with a staff of certified teachers and skilled volunteer tutors. Students attend on Saturdays between October and April for a half-day of focused academic skill-building. Professional teachers lead lessons, support volunteer tutors, and communicate with parents to keep them informed about their child’s progress. Volunteer tutors commit to a semester of volunteering in a classroom and mentor their students to provide consistent and individualized needed to succeed. Volunteer translators provide critical communication support between our GO families and our staff. Interpreters are responsible for translating English into Chinese (both Cantonese and Mandarin) in order for our program to communicate with our families regarding program updates and their child’s academic & social-emotional progress/needs. Specific Translator duties will include: Weekday Complete written translation of documents for the GO Project. Support with family outreach as needed. Provide interpretation for our families via phone or in office meetings, including any cultural/linguistic references that may need to be explained. Maintain our families’ right to confidentiality. 2017-2018 Schedule This position would require a commitment of 8 weekday hours (either 1 full day or two half days) between Tuesday to Friday. You would report to our main office 50 Cooper Square 3 rd Floor, New York, NY 10003. Qualifications: Excellent verbal and written communication skills. Interest in strength-based collaborative work, education and social services. Ability to speak Chinese (both Cantonese and Mandarin preferred) Prior experience in simultaneous and consecutive interpretation is a plus. Personal Attributes: The ideal candidate is exceptionally intelligent, warm, engaging and energetic. He or she also: Sees the possibilities as opposed to the obstacles and is creative and tenacious in solving problems. Enjoys working with others in a collaborative, creative environment. Has a strong work ethic and high standards for his/her own work and the work of others; is flexible and has a lively sense of humor. How to Apply Application Form Cover Letter/Personal Statement explaining why you want to volunteer with the GO Project Resume (for volunteers 18 and older)/ High school transcript (for HS students) Personal reference Background check (for those 18 and older) If interested, please fill out the online form at: https://goo.gl/forms/iGs9YOzEUsNCujrk2 . The online application form can also be found on the GO Project website: goprojectnyc.org under \"Get Involved\" and \"Volunteer Opportunities.\" If you have any questions or would like more information about the available volunteer positions, please contact Emily Ong, Community Engagement Program Manager, at eong@goprojectnyc.org.

10040.description: Volunteer with Behind the Book (www.behindthebook.org), a non-profit literacy organization that inspires New York City public school students to love reading. Through our innovative programs, accomplished authors lead workshops in high-needs pre-K-12 classrooms, where they guide students in creating their own writing and art projects based on the theme of the author's book. No experience or training is necessary to volunteer as a writing, research or art coach in the classroom. You'll support, engage, and encourage students as they work on their projects. This workshop needs your support in Washington Heights. To sign up, please contact volunteer@behindthebook.org with the program code. We'll supply the school address, directions, and other information when you're confirmed: Program 3226EO-P Date: Tuesday, December 12th, 2017 Time: 1:20 - 2:50 PM About the workshop: Sixth-graders read Marti’s Song for Freedomby Emma Otheguy, a bilingual biography of José Martí, a Cuban activist who dedicated his life to fighting for liberty, abolition of slavery, and Cuba’s political independence. The book is written in verse with excerpts from Martí’s seminal work, Versos sencillos. Students will go on a trip to explore Cuban culture and cuisine and, working with writing coaches, write short verses answering the question: What does freedom mean to you? To find other Behind the Book programs around the city, visit http://www.behindthebook.org/current-volunteer-opportunities/ To join our team and receive announcements of new volunteer opportunities as they're posted, please complete our brief questionnaire at http://www.behindthebook.org/join-us/volunteer/
10040.title: Writing coach for Washington Heights public school literacy program (322eop)

10035.description: We are currently accepting applications for Volunteer Dance Teachers for our Fall 2017 Program at Groove With Me, Inc. Groove With Me is a free dance school for girls in East Harlem. It engages girls during the idle out-of-school hours when 90% of youth violence occurs; and seeks to decrease teen pregnancy, truancy, crime, violence, prostitution, substance abuse and gang related activity. East Harlem has the highest unmet need for after school programming of any neighborhood in NYC. By volunteering you provide much needed out-of-school time safety - and arts programming. Classes are held after school between the hours of 4:00pm-8:00pm Monday through Friday and Saturdays 11:00am-3:00pm. If you are interested in this opportunity, or for further information please give me a call at 212-987-5910 or reach me via email at beatriz@groovewithme.org Beatriz Coronel, MA Program Director Groove With Me, Inc. 186 E 123rd St NY, NY 10035 Phone: 212-987-5910 Fax: 212-987-5080 www.groovewithme.org
10035.title: Volunteer Dance Teachers Needed for our Fall 2017 Program at Groove With Me, Inc.

10035.description: Reading Partners is currently recruiting volunteers for fall 2017! Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade. Reading is the foundation for all future learning. The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life. With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency. No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm. Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.
10035.title: Become a reading partner this fall- make a lifelong impact on a child (NYC)
