Help a student grow to be confident, caring young adult by becoming a role model and someone they can rely on. Mentors and mentees are matched after carefully considering the goals of the mentee and what the mentor can do to support that goal. We are currently looking for more male mentors. The mentoring program is for males and females, but as of now, we do not have enough male mentors.
10038.title: Middle School Mentor

10038.description: Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade. Reading is the foundation for all future learning.The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life. With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency. No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm. Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.
10038.title: Become a reading partner- make a lifelong impact on a child (PS 126 Jacob August Riis, Manhattan)

10038.description: The Refugee Resettlement Office of Catholic Charities Community Services provides assistance to refugees and asylees from diverse backgrounds, offering a variety of case management, employment, and educational services that help clients settle into their new community. To further help us with this goal the AmeriCorps VISTA member will be responsible for engaging volunteers, interns and parish/community/corporate volunteers to work with staff and support the programs. To read the full description, visit: http://www.catholiccharitiesnyvolunteer.org/NEW!
10038.title: AmeriCorps VISTA – Coordinator of Volunteers for New Americans
10038.org: Catholic Charities, Archdiocese of New York

10038.description: We are looking for volunteers with dance experience to help run a weekly movement-based creative workshop for students with intellectual disabilities in Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, Wednesdays from 11-12. This opportunity takes place over 12 weeks, for a small group of middle and high school students. The workshop will culminate with an informal showing. We are also looking for volunteer yoga instructors in all boroughs.
10038.title: Looking for Dance Teachers and Yoga Instructors

10013.description: Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, widely recognized as one of New York's premier human services providers, is a 123-year-old settlement house that provides an extensive array of effective and integrated services which significantly improve the lives of 15,000 people in need each year on the East Side of Manhattan. Our Senior Center at East 54th Street and Lexington Avenue is a vibrant program that provides hundreds of older adults with educational, cultural, health and social activities every week. We are seeking instructors for a variety of classes and activities including: Zumba Chair Yoga Mah Jong Line Dancing Conversational Italian Book Discussion Group Digital Photography Instructors lead their respective classes/activities once per week on weekdays. If you have one of the skills above and are interested in sharing your time and knowledge with active and enthusiastic older adults please contact Anthony Snowden, Volunteer Director at asnowden@lenoxhill.org or 212-218-0487.
10013.title: Instructor for Senior Center

10013.description: For many new immigrants, learning English is a first step to full participation in American society. Help them take that first step by becoming a volunteer teacher in English or Citizenship classes. English classes help students improve their communication skills. Citizenship classes help students prepare for the U.S. citizenship test. Volunteers work in teams to plan lessons and teach the class. This fun and rewarding experience gives you a chance to make a difference in the lives of others. Individuals with an interest in education careers are encouraged to apply. Requirements Must have good communication skills and a strong desire to help and work with new immigrants Prior teaching experience is preferred. Bilingual skills are a plus. We prefer volunteers who can commit to teaching at least two semesters Prospective volunteers must complete application and be interviewed. Volunteer Schedule: 9:30 am-11:30am (Tues or Thurs) 10:30 am-12:30 pm (Tues or Thurs) 1pm to 4pm (Saturday) 6:30pm to 8:30 pm (Mon, Tues or Wed) Fall 2017 - September 30, 2017 to December 16, 2017 Spring 2018 - March 4, 2018 to June 7, 2018 Summer 2018 - July 9, 2018 to August 18, 2018 Prospective volunteers must complete application and will be interviewed. Please contact us at cpanyc@cpanyc.org for an application OR apply on-line here: http://bit.ly/volunteerteacherapp For more information: http://bit.ly/VolunteerToTeachEnglishorCitizenshipClass
10013.title: Teach English or Citizenship Class in Chinatown

10012.description: ELVES WANTED! Brighten the holidays for a lonely senior (and yourself). We're looking for a few good elves to deliver gifts to homebound, isolated, and lonely senior citizens during the month of December. If you can volunteer to deliver gifts during the holiday season please send an email to HSquareVN@aol.com or call (212) 260-6200. *Gift Delivery begins Thursday, Dec. 7 and continues through Monday, Dec. 25. GROUPS AND CORPORATE TEAMS WELCOME!
10012.title: Christmas/Chanukah Elfing Project

10012.description: The Bubble Foundation Volunteer Wellness Educators teach wellness classes to pre-K and elementary students in one of our partner NYC schools (currently in Manhattan: East Harlem and the Bronx: Kingsbridge). Volunteers will use Bubble curricula to teach one or two interactive 45-min classes per week on topics relevant to food and health (e.g., cooking, nutrition, gardening, agriculture, food literacy). Wellness Educators are asked to commit to teach for the entire academic semester and will be paired with at least one co-teacher with complementary skills. We provide complete training to our volunteers and focus on professional development throughout the committed semester. Throughout this volunteer experience, Wellness Educators will gain skills in: nutrition education, garden education, culinary arts education, cooking, teaching, classroom management, teamwork, public speaking, working with kids who are challenged with health inequities. Thank you for your interest in volunteering with Bubble! Visit welcometobubble.org/wellness- educator-program to learn more and apply. Questions? Please contact: volunteer@welcometobubble.org
10012.title: Nutrition, Cooking, and Gardening Wellness Educator

10011.description: Do you have a passion for dance? Do you enjoy working with children? Are you looking to gain experience and new skills? then volunteering with Dance to Unite, Inc. could be the right volunteer opportunity for you! Dance to Unite, Inc. is a non-profit organization whose mission is to use dance as a vehicle to teach and to celebrate cultural diversity. WE ARE LOOKING FOR VOLUNTEER DANCE TEACHERS AND TEACHER ASSISTANTS! Qualified applicants are required to have some background in dance but most imporatntly a strong interest and desire to work with inner city children and youth. A one hour weekly comittment is required throughout the school year (October-June) and availability during after-school hours (3:00-6:00pm). We offer FREE training in a warm and supportive environment with plently of opportunities for professional and personal growth. Responsibilities of Volunteer Dance Teachers: -Become familiar and comfortable with implementing our educational component which includes leading our 5-10 minutes 'Circle Talk' . *We provide supervision, guidance and support to ensure that everyone is properly trained and fully prepared to implement our educational component. -Create and teach a year-round dance routine and choose the music that will accompany your choreography. -Facilitate one special guest artist workshop (which is offered to each Dance to Unite, Inc. Class throught the school year) by briefing students about the style of dance or other artistic medium which is explored that day and collaborate with all those involved in making the workshop a success. Responsibilities of Dance Teacher Assistants: -Work closely with a teacher and support her/his efforts in fulfilling all of her/his duties/responsibilities. -Participate in/or lead a weekly warm-up exercise routine. -Learn the choreography taught by the teacher by rehearsing a weekly dance routine with the students. -Assist the teacher with running/managing the classroom by providing positive feedback and addressing inappropriate behaviors when needed. -Periodically take photos/videos that can be used for our social media (using a camera phone). Benefits of these volunteer opportunities: -Gain knowledge/experience and develop various set of skills related to creating a year-round dance choreography, leading a short discussion and managing a classroom. -Receive references and recommendation letters as evidence to support your accomplishments when applying for internships, jobs or graduate schools. *Internship opportunities are available to both high school and college students. -Recieve free training in a warm and supportive environment that offers countless opportunities for professional and personal growth. -Volunteers who have been with us long enough to show commitment and dedication to our organization are acknowledged by being featured on our organization's website. -Cultivate new personal and professional contacts. -Receive a free invitation to our annual benefit and other events. -Join our Dance to Unite, Inc. Meetup group and meet like-minded people in the local community who share a passion for making a difference. THANK YOU FOR YOUR INTEREST IN JOINING OUR DANCE TO UNITE FAMILY! For further information, please check our website: www.dancetounite.org FOR QUESTIONS AND INQUIRIES, PLEASE CONTACT: info@dancetounite.org
10011.title: Teach dance to inner city kids!

10011.description: GRANT WRITER The Grant Writer is primarily responsible for developing and writing grant proposals to foundations and other grant-making organizations, and will persuasively communicate CSP's mission and programs to potential funders. Reporting to the Executive Director, the Grant Writer will assemble and submit grant requests, establish and maintain personal contact and relationships with foundation contacts, conduct prospect research, and maintain a calendar of submissions and other deadlines. To get a response please send RESUME.
10011.title: Grant Writer

10011.description: Computer/It - Tech Support - All aspects of tech support for the organization including maintenance, troubleshoot, specially ANTI-VIRUS, and optimal functioning of the system. Must have experience with Microsoft and Windows systems. To get a response please send RESUME .
10011.title: Computer support

10011.description: Education Program Coordinator - Chelsea Sculpture Park. New York , New York. Basic Requirements: BA or MA in related discipline required (Art Education) Post college professional work experience required Demonstrated experience with art education or other informal art programming and curriculum design Demonstrated knowledge of Microsoft computer programs and excellent presentation skills Job Responsibilities: Coordinate and develop of new partner-institution/organization relationships and curriculum Provide leadership and direction towards the design and implementation of art educational programming and curriculum in compliance with national and state learning objectives, accreditation guidelines, and innovative art methodologies Establish and grow professional relationships with constituents, peers, associations and partner schools To Apply: Please submit your resume with cover letter and references to the contact information listed below. Set against the backdrop of the Hudson River, Chelsea Sculpture Park will offer fine art for the public to experience, up close and outdoors. The park's mission is to provide an aesthetic oasis in the Chelsea Cove section of Hudson River Park located between 22nd and 26th Streets, just steps away from the world-class Chelsea Art District. We are looking for a Education Program Coordinator to assist the founder and executive-director of Chelsea Sculpture Park develop and implement an educational program foccusing on the exhibitions of the sculpture park.
10011.title: Educational Program - Coordinator

10011.description: Chelsea Sculpture Park New York, New York Are you considering a future in arts administration, nonprofit management, fundraising, arts education or a related field? This is a great opportunity to gain experience working at a brand new nonprofit arts organization that is dedicated to building a sculpture park on the banks of the Hudson River Park. Gain invaluable insights and learn fundraising strategies as part of a dynamic Development team. Assist with prospect research, special events, direct mail, and our donor database, as well as pursue special projects. Internship credit may be arranged through your academic program. The ideal candidate will be organized and detail-oriented, and have good computer skills. Those with prospect research experience and graduate students in arts administration and arts education are especially welcome. The hours for this position are flexible within the work week. A modest stipend is available. To Apply: Please be sure to include current contact information so that we may arrange an interview. To get a response please send RESUME .
10011.title: Development Intern

10036.description: The Icla da Silva Foundation is a nonprofit that helps patients who need a bone marrow transplant. We recently had our shipment of holiday cards come to the office and we realized that 5,000 holiday cards is too many for a staff of 2 to do on their own! I'd like to ask your help in stuffing, labeling, and stamping these cards that we will send to our amazing donors, supporters, and friends. Would you be willing to help us? Our new office is located at: 311 West 43rd Street, 11th floor New York, NY 10036 We are looking for volunteers to come in any time between 10am - 4pm tomorrow, Thursday, December 7th, Friday, December 8th, and Monday, December 11th. If you're interested, please click here to sign up to be a volunteer. Please select a date and time and just add your first and last name to the timeslot of your choice. When I see that you've added your name, I'll reach out to you to confirm. If you want to bring a friend then please do - the more the merrier!
10036.title: Holiday Mailing Help

10036.description: Project FIND- Coffeehouse Annual Christmas Dinner for senior Citizens Volunteers needed two different Days December 22, 2017, 3:30 pm to 5:00 pm Help pack 300 gift bags to be given out Christmas day, help dress tables and decorate. December 25, 2017- 9:30 am to 2:00 Complete Decorations Deliver 75 Dinners to Home bound seniors Serve Dinner to seniors Because we only need 60 volunteers please register and confirm as soon as possible. List will close as soon as we reach that amount. If you are interested contact descort@projectfind.org Confirm by sending your full name and e-mail information. Visit our web-site: www.projectfind.org
10036.title: Christmas Celebration of Giving

10036.description: LiveOn NY is hosting their 28th Annual Conference on Aging & Vendor Expo! Leaders and professionals in the aging field will come together at this event to network, share innovative ideas and more! We are in need of volunteers to help us stuff and pack bags for the attendees. Days needed: Thursday, January 18 & Friday, January 19 If you are available on both days, reach out the Victoria! vthornton@liveon-ny.org 212-398-6565 ext 235
10036.title: Bag Stuffing for Annual Conference!

10036.description: We are in need of a creative movement, beginner modern dance teacher for our Wednesday's youth arts program! Teaching ages 4-6yrs old from 4:00-4:45pm. Love of dance, movement, children, and teaching is a must! Come dance with us!
10036.title: Children's Creative Movement Teacher for Salvation Army

10036.description: In need of a hip hop dance teacher, to instruct our Wednesday night youth programs! Class is from 6-6:45pm, and ages range from 6-12yrs old. Takes place in our Times Square building, in a large beautiful studio with new wooden floors, barres, and mirrors. Love of dance, teaching, and working with kids is a must! Come dance with us!
10036.title: Children's hip hop teacher needed at Salvation Army!

10036.description: The Salvation Army of Times Square is in need of two ballet teachers to instruct our 6-13yr olds. Basic beginner level ballet technique, love of children, and passion for teaching is a must! Starting in Jan. of 2018! We have a beautiful large dance studio with new wooden floors, barres, and mirrors. Come dance with our cute kiddos!
10036.title: Childrens' Ballet Teacher needed at the Salvation Army!

10036.description: Theater 315 of the Salvation Army at Times Square, is in need of a Drama teacher for their 2018 semester. You would be teaching acting to a group of about 10 young artists, ages 8-12yrs old, each Wednesday from 6-6:45pm.
10036.title: Children's Drama Teacher Needed!

10036.description: Centro NYC, a non-profit organization serving the immigrant community in New York City, seeks a volunteer ESL teacher for its fall term, beginning immediately and continuing through mid-December. However, we encourage you continue to volunteer with us in the following semester. Classroom English teaching experience is welcome. You will be partnered with and mentored by an experienced teacher. Time commitment: one night per week teaching plus the time required for lesson preparation (usually every other week.) Classes meet Mondays, Wednesdays, and Thursdays from 6:15-9:00 p.m. in midtown Manhattan. We have at least one opening on Wednesday evening to work with our intermediate to advanced students, all adults, but other opportunities may be available. Please respond by email to Danielle at info@CentroNYC.org. Include your resume and tell us the evening(s) that you're available for teaching.
10036.title: Volunteer English / ESL Teacher to Adults -- Immediate Opportunity!

10036.description: Centro NYC, a non-profit organization serving the immigrant community in New York City, seeks a volunteer ESL teacher for its fall term, beginning immediately and continuing through mid-December. However, we encourage you continue to volunteer with us in the following semester. Classroom English teaching experience is welcome. You will be partnered with and mentored by an experienced teacher. Time commitment: one night per week teaching plus the time required for lesson preparation (usually every other week.) Classes meet Mondays, Wednesdays, and Thursdays from 6:15-9:00 p.m. in midtown Manhattan. We have at least one opening on Wednesday evening to work with our intermediate to advanced students, but other opportunities may be available. Please respond by email to Danielle at info@CentroNYC.org. Include your resume and tell us the evening(s) that you're available for teaching.
10036.title: Adult English / ESL Teacher – VOLUNTEER NEEDED!

10036.description: Hola! Somos una organización sin fines de lucro que ayuda a la comunidad inmigrante latina y no latina de Nueva York en el aprendizaje del idioma inglés, en la preparación para el examen de ciudadanía estadounidense y en el desarrollo de otras actividades de empoderamiento para la comunidad inmigrante. También ofrecemos clases de español para no hispanohablantes, con lo cual contribuimos además a la difusión de la cultura y valores hispanos en los Estados Unidos. Estamos a la búsqueda de profesores de Español (voluntarios) para nuestras clases de Otoño 2017 (septiembre - diciembre 2017) que empiezan el 18 de septiembre. Las clases son una vez por semana de 6:15 pm a 9:00 pm. Esta es una posición de voluntariado (sin pago). Habrá una sesión de entrenamiento previo al inicio de clases el jueves 14 de septiembre de 2017 en la noche. Si te gusta ayudar a la gente y a la comunidad por favor comunícate con nosotros respondiendo este aviso. Muchas gracias!
10036.title: Volunteer Spanish Teachers / Profesores de Español (voluntarios)

10017.description: ALSAC is the fundraising and awareness organization for St. Jude Children's Research Hospital. We are looking for passionate and driven volunteers who are ready to make a difference for St. Jude. We are recruiting volunteers to help for few hours Monday-Friday with office related work during the holiday season. Please contact Fatima Hameed for more information! Fatima Hameed Admin Volunteer Coordinator ALSAC, the fundraising and awareness organization for St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital(r) 220 E 42 nd St, Suite 435, New York, NY 10017 Office: 212-379-1600 Email: Fatima.hameed@stjude.org
10017.title: ALSAC-St. Jude in Office Volunteering

10016.description: We are looking for volunteers who would be willing to help out with our annual holiday party. We would like our volunteers to help bring food to the second floor of the building where the sit-down dinner takes place. During the dinner, we would like help with taking away empty dishes. If that is something that you would like to help out, please get in touch with us, we would truly appreciate your help. Please note that the opportunity entails walking up and down the stairs several times throughout the night.
10016.title: Servers needed for our Christmas Party

10016.description: Volunteers needed to help disabled people with shopping, running errands and reading mail to the blind. If interested call 718-606-9712 This the 3rd Saturday of every month
10016.title: Be A Friend Day
10016.org: Helping Hands for the Disabled of NYC

10016.description: GO Project Spanish Translator (Saturday Volunteer) GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Programming: How YOU Can Help GO Schoolis a focused, seven-month Saturday program with a staff of certified teachers and skilled volunteer tutors. Students attend on Saturdays between October and April for a half-day of focused academic skill-building. Professional teachers lead lessons, support volunteer tutors, and communicate with parents to keep them informed about their child’s progress. Volunteer tutors commit to a semester of volunteering in a classroom and mentor their students to provide consistent and individualized needed to succeed. Volunteer translators provide critical communication support between our GO families and our staff. Interpreters are responsible for translating English into Spanish in order for our program to communicate with our families regarding program updates and their child’s academic & social-emotional progress/needs. Specific Translator duties will include: Saturdays Assist with parent meetings, workshops and orientations for Spanish speaking families. Provide interpretation for our families, including any cultural/linguistic references that may need to be explained. Maintain our families’ right to confidentiality. Collaborate with GO Staff, Volunteer Manager, Head Teachers and GO Families Staff to address and respond to our students’/ families’ needs. Time Commitment The position would require a commitment to our GO School Saturday program. We can accommodate a semester schedule or a full year commitment. Session I: October- December 2017, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2018, 13 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications: Excellent verbal and written communication skills. Interest in strength-based collaborative work, education and social services. Ability to speak Spanish. Prior experience in simultaneous and consecutive interpretation is a plus. Personal Attributes: The ideal candidate is exceptionally intelligent, warm, engaging and energetic. He or she also: Sees the possibilities as opposed to the obstacles and is creative and tenacious in solving problems. Enjoys working with others in a collaborative, creative environment. Has a strong work ethic and high standards for his/her own work and the work of others; is flexible and has a lively sense of humor. Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development and training opportunities. Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment. Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community. How to Apply Application Form Cover Letter/Personal Statement explaining why you want to volunteer with the GO Project Resume (for volunteers 18 and older)/ High school transcript (for HS students) Personal reference Background check (for those 18 and older) If interested, please fill out the online form at: https://goo.gl/forms/iGs9YOzEUsNCujrk2 . The online application form can also be found on the GO Project website: goprojectnyc.org under \"Get Involved\" and \"Volunteer Opportunities.\" If you have any questions or would like more information about the available volunteer positions, please contact Emily Ong, Community Engagement Program Manager, at eong@goprojectnyc.
10016.title: Saturday Spanish Translator Needed!

10016.description: READING BUDDY PLUS connects a younger child with the same adult volunteer every other Tuesday from October- June. Every time they visit the Reading Center, children share a story one-on-one with the same buddy. This continuity offers a child the same opportunity to improve their reading skills and open up their imagination, but more importantly it gives them the chance to deepen the bonds and their sense of trust with one person. As their friendships with the children evolve, volunteers can better help the children in this program to see their world in a more positive light. And, in talking about the stories they share, the children can learn to use their imaginations to make a difference in their own lives. http://pajamaprogram.org/ Requirements and Commitments: ALL volunteers must pass a background check and fill out a volunteer application to be able to participate in Reading Buddy Plus. All personal information will be kept confidential. This program runs every other Tuesday from 12 P.M. - 1 P.M. from October- June. Volunteers MUST commit to the ENTIRE school year. If interested, please email Chrissie Martinez at chrissie@pajamaprogram.org to receive further information.
10016.title: Share the Joy of Reading with a Child

10016.description: GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Tutoring: How YOU Can Help During the GO School Saturday program, a professional teacher models a lesson, activity or project to a classroom of students. Volunteer tutors continue to work with small groups of (2) to (4) students on the lesson providing individualized attention which allows the students to thrive. Tutor Responsibilities Tutor small group of students in grades 1 st-8 th who are in need of academic intervention under Head Teacher’s guidance Punctual and consistent attendance; no more than 3 absences permitted per session. (Session 1: Oct-Dec, Session 2: Jan-April) Actively and enthusiastically participate - supporting instruction and engagement Help prepare, record and put away classroom materials Ongoing communication with Head Teacher regarding children’s progress &/or concerns, and with the Director of Community Engagement regarding overall volunteer experience. Time Commitment Session I: October- December 2017, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2018, 14 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Attend mandatory orientation and training prior to start of session. *You can choose to be a Committed Volunteer to come each Saturday with 3 allowed absences per session, or a Floater Volunteer to come on the Saturdays that you are available. GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations You can choose to tutor our students at one of the following 6 locations: Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications College students, professionals, retirees, and high school students in good academic standing. Commitment to and belief in all children’s ability to succeed and thrive Professional work habits Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development and training opportunities. Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment. Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community. How to Apply Application Form Cover Letter/Personal Statement explaining why you want to volunteer with the GO Project Resume (for volunteers 18 and older)/ High school transcript (for HS students) Personal reference Background check (for those 18 and older) If interested, please fill out the online form at: https://goo.gl/forms/iGs9YOzEUsNCujrk2 . The online application form can also be found on the GO Project website: goprojectnyc.org under \"Get Involved\" and \"Volunteer Opportunities.\" If you have any questions or would like more information about the available volunteer positions, please contact Emily Ong, Community Engagement Program Manager, at eong@goprojectnyc.org.
10016.title: Help a Child Love to Learn: Volunteer Tutor with GO Project!

10016.description: GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Programming: How YOU Can Help GO Schoolis a focused, seven-month Saturday program with a staff of certified teachers and skilled volunteer tutors. Students attend on Saturdays between October and April for a half-day of focused academic skill-building. Professional teachers lead lessons, support volunteer tutors, and communicate with parents to keep them informed about their child’s progress. Volunteer tutors commit to a semester of volunteering in a classroom and mentor their students to provide consistent and individualized needed to succeed. Volunteer translators provide critical communication support between our GO families and our staff. Interpreters are responsible for translating English into Chinese (both Mandarin and Cantonese) in order for our program to communicate with our families regarding program updates and their child’s academic & social-emotional progress/needs. Specific Translator duties will include: Saturdays Assist with parent meetings, workshops and orientations for Chinese speaking families. Provide interpretation for our families, including any cultural/linguistic references that may need to be explained. Maintain our families’ right to confidentiality. Collaborate with GO Staff, Volunteer Manager, Head Teachers and GO Families Staff to address and respond to our students’/ families’ needs. Time Commitment The position would require a commitment to our GO School Saturday program. We can accommodate a semester schedule or a full year commitment. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications: Excellent verbal and written communication skills. Interest in strength-based collaborative work, education and social services. Ability to speak both Mandarin and Cantonese is preferred. Prior experience in simultaneous and consecutive interpretation is a plus. Personal Attributes: The ideal candidate is exceptionally intelligent, warm, engaging and energetic. Has a strong work ethic and high standards for his/her own work and the work of others; is flexible and has a lively sense of humor. Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development and training opportunities. 10014.description: GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Tutoring: How YOU Can Help During the GO School Saturday program, a professional teacher models a lesson, activity, or project to a classroom of students. Volunteer tutors continue to work with small groups of 2-4 students on the lesson, providing individualized attention which allows the students to thrive. Tutor Responsibilities Tutor small group of students in grades 1st-8th who are in need of academic intervention under Head Teacher’s guidance Punctual and consistent attendance; no more than 3 absences permitted per session (Session I: October-December, Session II: January-April) Actively and enthusiastically participate - support instruction and engagement Help prepare, record, and put away classroom materials Ongoing communication with Head Teacher regarding students’ progress and/or concerns, and with the Senior Director of Community Engagement regarding overall volunteer experience Time Commitment Session I: October-December 2017; 9 Saturdays from 9:00AM-12:45PM Session II: January-April 2018; 14 Saturdays from 9:00AM-12:45PM Attend mandatory orientation and training prior to start of session. *You can choose to be a Committed Volunteer to come each Saturday with 3 allowed absences per session, or a Floater Volunteer to come on the Saturdays that you are available. GO School Fall 2017 Session I October 14, 21, 28 November 4, 11, 18 December 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring 2018 Session II January 6, 20, 27 February 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations You can choose to tutor our students at one of the following 6 locations: Manhattan Locations Avenues: The World School (1st-5th Grade): 259 10th Avenue, between 25th and 26th Streets Grace Church School (1st-5th Grade): 86 4th Avenue, between 10th and 11th Streets Grace Church High School (6th-8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6th Street LREI (1st-5th Grade): 272 6th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s School (1st-3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson and Christopher Streets Brooklyn Location Berkeley Carroll (1st- 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6th and 7th Avenues Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications College students, professionals, retirees, and high school students in good academic standing Commitment to and belief in all children’s ability to succeed and thrive Professional work habits Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners Ongoing professional development and training opportunities Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community How to Apply Application Form Cover Letter/Personal Statement explaining why you want to volunteer with GO Project Resume (for volunteers 18 and older)/High school transcript (for high school students) Personal reference Background check (for those 18 and older) If interested, please fill out the online form at: https://goo.gl/forms/iGs9YOzEUsNCujrk2. The online application form can also be found on our website at: http://goprojectnyc.org/get-involved/volunteer. If you have any questions or would like more information about the available volunteer positions, please contact volunteering@goprojectnyc.org or call 212-533-3744 ATTN: Olivia Nunez, Senior Director of Community Engagement.

10014.title: Saturday Spanish Translator Needed!

10014.description: GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Tutoring: How YOU Can Help During the GO School Saturday program, a professional teacher models a lesson, activity or project to a classroom of students. Volunteer tutors continue to work with small groups of (2) to (4) students on the lesson providing individualized attention which allows the students to thrive. Tutor Responsibilities Tutor small group of students in grades 1 st-8 th who are in need of academic intervention under Head Teacher’s guidance Punctual and consistent attendance; no more than 3 absences permitted per session. (Session 1: Oct-Dec, Session 2: Jan-April) Actively and enthusiastically participate - supporting instruction and engagement Help prepare, record and put away classroom materials Ongoing communication with Head Teacher regarding children’s progress &/or concerns, and with the Director of Community Engagement regarding overall volunteer experience. Time Commitment Session I: October- December 2017, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2018, 14 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Attend mandatory orientation and training prior to start of session. *You can choose to be a Committed Volunteer to come each Saturday with 3 allowed absences per session, or a Floater Volunteer to come on the Saturdays that you are available. GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations You can choose to tutor our students at one of the following 6 locations: Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications College students, professionals, retirees, and high school students in good academic standing. Commitment to and belief in all children’s ability to succeed and thrive Professional work habits Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. 10014.description: GO Project Spanish Translator (Saturday Volunteer) GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Programming: How YOU Can Help GO Schoolis a focused, seven-month Saturday program with a staff of certified teachers and skilled volunteer tutors. Students attend on Saturdays between October and April for a half-day of focused academic skill-building. Professional teachers lead lessons, support volunteer tutors, and communicate with parents to keep them informed about their child’s progress. Volunteer tutors commit to a semester of volunteering in a classroom and mentor their students to provide consistent and individualized needed to succeed. Volunteer translators provide critical communication support between our GO families and our staff. Interpreters are responsible for translating English into Spanish in order for our program to communicate with our families regarding program updates and their child’s academic & social-emotional progress/needs. Specific Translator duties will include: Saturdays Assist with parent meetings, workshops and orientations for Spanish speaking families. Provide interpretation for our families, including any cultural/linguistic references that may need to be explained. Maintain our families’ right to confidentiality. Collaborate with GO Staff, Volunteer Manager, Head Teachers and GO Families Staff to address and respond to our students’/ families’ needs. Time Commitment The position would require a commitment to our GO School Saturday program. We can accommodate a semester schedule or a full year commitment. Session I: October- December 2017, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2018, 13 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications: Excellent verbal and written communication skills. Interest in strength-based collaborative work, education and social services. Ability to speak Spanish. Prior experience in simultaneous and consecutive interpretation is a plus. Personal Attributes: The ideal candidate is exceptionally intelligent, warm, engaging and energetic. He or she also: Sees the possibilities as opposed to the obstacles and is creative and tenacious in solving problems. Enjoys working with others in a collaborative, creative environment. Has a strong work ethic and high standards for his/her own work and the work of others; is flexible and has a lively sense of humor. Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development and training opportunities. Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment. Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community. How to Apply Application Form Cover Letter/Personal Statement explaining why you want to volunteer with the GO Project Resume (for volunteers 18 and older)/ High school transcript (for HS students) Personal reference Background check (for those 18 and older) If interested, please fill out the online form at: https://goo.gl/forms/iGs9YOzEUsNCujrk2 . 10014.title: Saturday Chinese Translators Needed!

10014.description: GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Tutoring: How YOU Can Help During the GO School Saturday program, a professional teacher models a lesson, activity or project to a classroom of students. Volunteer tutors continue to work with small groups of (2) to (4) students on the lesson providing individualized attention which allows the students to thrive. Tutor Responsibilities Tutor small group of students in grades 1 st-8 th who are in need of academic intervention under Head Teacher’s guidance Punctual and consistent attendance; no more than 3 absences permitted per session. (Session 1: Oct-Dec, Session 2: Jan-April) Actively and enthusiastically participate - supporting instruction and engagement Help prepare, record and put away classroom materials Ongoing communication with Head Teacher regarding children’s progress &/or concerns, and with the Director of Community Engagement regarding overall volunteer experience. Time Commitment Session I: October- December 2017, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2018, 14 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Attend mandatory orientation and training prior to start of session. *You can choose to be a Committed Volunteer to come each Saturday with 3 allowed absences per session, or a Floater Volunteer to come on the Saturdays that you are available. GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations You can choose to tutor our students at one of the following 6 locations: Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications College students, professionals, retirees, and high school students in good academic standing. Commitment to and belief in all children’s ability to succeed and thrive Professional work habits Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development and training opportunities. Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment. Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community. Volunteer tutors continue to work with small groups of (2) to (4) students on the lesson providing individualized attention which allows the students to thrive. Tutor Responsibilities Tutor small group of students in grades 1 st-8 th who are in need of academic intervention under Head Teacher’s guidance Punctual and consistent attendance; no more than 3 absences permitted per session. (Session 1: Oct-Dec, Session 2: Jan-April) Actively and enthusiastically participate - supporting instruction and engagement Help prepare, record and put away classroom materials Ongoing communication with Head Teacher regarding children’s progress &/or concerns, and with the Director of Community Engagement regarding overall volunteer experience. Time Commitment Session I: October- December 2017, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2018, 14 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Attend mandatory orientation and training prior to start of session. *You can choose to be a Committed Volunteer to come each Saturday with 3 allowed absences per session, or a Floater Volunteer to come on the Saturdays that you are available. GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations You can choose to tutor our students at one of the following 6 locations: Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications College students, professionals, retirees, and high school students in good academic standing. Commitment to and belief in all children’s ability to succeed and thrive Professional work habits Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development and training opportunities. Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment. Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community. How to Apply Application Form Cover Letter/Personal Statement explaining why you want to volunteer with the GO Project Resume (for volunteers 18 and older)/ High school transcript (for HS students) Personal reference Background check (for those 18 and older) If interested, please fill out the online form at: https://goo.gl/forms/iGs9YOzEUsNCujrk2 . The online application form can also be found on the GO Project website: goprojectnyc.org under \"Get Involved\" and \"Volunteer Opportunities.\" If you have any questions or would like more information about the available volunteer positions, please contact Emily Ong, Community Engagement Program Manager, at eong@goprojectnyc.org.
10014.title: Help a Child Love to Learn: Volunteer Tutor with GO Project!

10014.description: The National Audubon Society’s volunteer program aims to inspire lifelong stewardship of our environment and communities, providing individuals the opportunity to develop skills needed for a successful career in conservation. Currently, volunteer opportunities are being offered in the area of Environmental Education.  Audubon invites you to become a volunteer with Audubon New York’s premier environmental education program, For the Birds! ( FTB!) NYC.  For the Birds! is a place-based elementary education program that teaches environmental awareness and appreciation of nature through the study of birds. During multiple visits, students in grades two through six learn about their local, natural environment through indoor and outdoor lessons, field trips, and a conservation project designed to provide or enhance bird habitat in the local community.   For the Birds! volunteers will assist with the implementation of the FTB! program in New York City schools and camps throughout all five boroughs.  S/he will teach this program to multiple classes / summer camps in New York City and will also assist the FTB! Program Director with administrative duties related to the delivery and expansion of the program.  This includes, but is not limited to: curriculum development and revision, materials preparation and inventory, school set up, follow up and wrap up, and other administrative duties as needed. Volunteers will work closely with the FTB! Program Director to inspire a new generation of conservationists through the study of birds.   Interns will gain experience s in both formal and non-formal environmental education and learn valuable and transferable skills such as project management, curriculum development, volunteer management, and community engagement.
10014.title: Audubon NY's For the Birds! Education Program
